newsitem.title: USA: Hurricane may again delay pickup of U.S. astronaut.
newsitem.headline: Hurricane may again delay pickup of U.S. astronaut.

text.p: Hurricane Fran, lurking in the Atlantic, may further delay the launching of a space shuttle meant to take U.S. astronaut Shannon Lucid off Russia's Mir space station, NASA officials said on Tuesday.
The shuttle Atlantis, already six weeks late because of rocket problems, is supposed to take Lucid back to Earth after dropping off her replacement, John Blaha.
Lucid, a 53-year-old mother of three, has been working aboard the space station since March. She was originally due home in August.
"We'll get her back as soon as we can," NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said. "It's another short delay if it turns out to be that at all."
NASA has been poised since Friday to haul the shuttle off its seaside launch pad at the Kennedy Space Centre if Hurricane Fran threatened the east coast of Florida.
With launch preparations virtually on hold while NASA managers monitor the storm, it may prove impossible to launch Atlantis as planned on Sept. 14.
"Even if we stay on the pad, it's going to be very tight, but we're not prepared to give up yet," Buckingham said.
Officials will decide on Tuesday night whether to move Atlantis back to the safety of its giant assembly building. That would almost certainly mean a delay.
"It's going to be a close call whether we come back or not," Buckingham said. "They'll make a decision one way or another tonight."
Hurricane Fran is also likely to delay the planned Oct. 31 launch of the shuttle Columbia, because work to assemble its booster rockets has been held up for almost a week.
And two unmanned rockets scheduled to be launched from Cape Canaveral Air Station next week may face delays because of the storm.
